ğŸ’¡ Ever wondered how Java manages memory so efficiently when dealing with strings? Letâ€™s dive into the concept of the Java String Pool and uncover its significance. ğŸš€ğŸ§µ What is the Java String Pool?The Java String Pool is a special area in the heap memory ğŸ§  where Java stores string literals. When you create a string literal, Java checks the pool to see if an identical string already exists. If it does, Java reuses the reference, saving memory and improving performance. This process is called string interning ğŸ”.ğŸ’ Why is it Important?ğŸ”¹ Memory Optimization: Reuses immutable string objects to reduce   memory overhead. ğŸ”¹ Performance Enhancement: Less memory usage = faster garbage collection ğŸ§¹ and smoother app performance âš¡. ğŸ”¹ Consistency: Identical string literals share the same reference, ensuring consistency across the application. âœ”ï¸ String a = "Java"; String b = "Java"; System.out.println(a == b); // Outputs: true âœ…ğŸ“Œ Key Takeaway:Understanding the String Pool helps you write memory-efficient Java applications ğŸ’¼. It's a subtle yet powerful feature that underscores Javaâ€™s design for performance and reliability. ğŸ› ï¸hashtag#Java hashtag#StringPool hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#JavaMemory hashtag#JavaOptimization hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#MemoryManagement

But in the meantime, global remote work gives people here a way to level up their lives.Thatâ€™s a win in my book.

Title: Java Program to Analyze Student MarksIntroduction:This Java program is designed to assist in analyzing student performance by collecting marks for a fixed set of subjects and then computing useful insights such as the total marks, average, highest and lowest marks, and the corresponding subjects.Functionality Overview:The program begins by prompting the user to enter marks for a predefined list of subjects: Tamil, English, Maths, Science, and Social. The marks entered by the user are stored in an integer array.Core Processing:Once the marks are collected, the program performs the following tasks:1. Total Marks Calculation: It adds up all the marks using a loop.2. Average Marks: The total is divided by the number of subjects to get the average.3. Identifying Extremes: It finds the highest and lowest marks by comparing each subject's score. Along with the marks, the program also tracks which subjects have these scores.Output:After processing the data, the program displays:Total marksAverage marksThe subject with the highest marksThe subject with the lowest marksConclusion:This program is a simple yet effective example of how arrays, loops, and conditionals can be used in Java to manage and analyze student data. It helps reinforce key programming concepts while being practical for real-world applications like report card generation.hashtag#snsinstitutions hashtag#snsdesignthikers hashtag#designthinking

Day 20 of 100daysofcudaprogramming: - Chapter 6 of the PMPP book completed- CUDA Optimization Checklist:- 1. Maximize Occupancy: a. Hides pipeline/memory latency. b. Tune threads/block, shared memory, registers.- 2. Coalesced Global Memory Accesses: a. Reduces memory traffic, stalls. b. Load coalesced to shared memory, rearrange thread/data mapping.- 3. Minimize Control Divergence: a. Improves SIMD efficiency b. Align thread workloads, rearrange data- 4. Tile Reused Data: a. Cuts global memory accesses b. Store tiles in shared memory/registers- 5. Privatization: a. Avoids atomic contention b. Use private copies, update universal copy later- 6. Thread Coarsening: a. Reduces redundant work/sync b. Assign multiple tasks per thread

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

ğŸš€ Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! ğŸš€1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize â€“ 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2Ã—blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.ğŸ”¹ Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isnâ€™t a multiple of 2Ã—blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.ğŸ“‚ Check out the code and follow along: ğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: ğŸ’¬ Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? ğŸ‘ Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

Some thoughts on hashtag#remoteWorkI donâ€™t think I need to explain how remote work has evolved in recent years. Before COVID-19 (pre-2021), remote work was a rare privilegeâ€”something only a lucky few could negotiate. But during the pandemic, it became the norm, especially in computer-based fields like software engineering, analytics, and marketing.Over the past few months, however, we've seen increasing pushback. Some companies have gone as far as mandating a full return to the officeâ€”not just hybrid, but five days a week. I wanted to reflect on what feels like a regression.I call it a regression because, had it not been for a global pandemic, many companies would still believe that productivity could only be guaranteed through physical presenceâ€”by clocking in and out, sitting at a desk under watchful eyes. But we proved otherwise. Productivity didnâ€™t tank. The world didnâ€™t stop. The sun didnâ€™t rise from the west.That said, remote work wasnâ€™t without its challenges. Some individuals abused the flexibilityâ€”juggling multiple full-time roles at once and damaging the trust-based relationship needed for remote work to thrive.Iâ€™ve also noticed that some recent graduates, who entered the workforce in this new remote-first world, struggled with engagement. Thrust into what felt like a dream scenario, some lacked the structure or mentorship that in-person environments naturally provideâ€”leading to performance issues.But letâ€™s not allow a few bad examples to overshadow the bigger picture. Remote work may be one of the greatest professional shifts of our time. At least for me, hereâ€™s what itâ€™s meant:1.  I gained back over 2 hours a day from commutingâ€”thatâ€™s 700 hours a year. Less commuting = less stress and wasted energy = more productivity.2. Thatâ€™s time I now spend with my family, myselfâ€”or yes, sometimes, even working.3. Most importantly, I got to watch my baby girl grow up. Every day. From the moment she was born until now, two years later, Iâ€™ve seen her in her element. Thatâ€™s priceless. Itâ€™s something many of our fathers missedâ€”and I donâ€™t think we should repeat that mistake.4. I have more control over my timSo how do we make remote work a win-win?1. Trust, but verify: Build accountability through regular check-ins, clear deliverables, and performance metrics.2. Hybrid mentorship: Pair remote flexibility with in-person or virtual mentorship to support junior talent.3. Cultural investment: Create intentional moments for team bonding and alignmentâ€”digitally or otherwise.4. Results over hours: Focus on outcomes, not desk time. Empower employees to own their time.Remote work isnâ€™t perfectâ€”but neither was the old way. Letâ€™s not lose sight of the enormous good it can bring, when done right. Iâ€™m genuinely grateful to Klarna for embracing this cultureâ€”striking a healthy balance between drive and productivity, while honoring the importance of family and well-being. Letâ€™s evolve, not revert.hashtag#remotework hashtag#futureofwork hashtag#productivity

Other times, it looks like sitting in a hottub in the mountains with a viewâ€”laptop closed, soaking in the freedom you built.Working from home is really about working from anywhere.Itâ€™s about building a life where you donâ€™t have to choose between time with your family and building your future.I used to think freedom was just a dream. ğŸš€ Day 11 of my 30 Days Java & DSA Challenge ğŸ¯ Topic: Compile-Time Polymorphism in Java (Method Overloading)Today, I explored one of the foundational OOP concepts in Javaâ€”Polymorphism, specifically Method Overloading. Itâ€™s all about writing multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or orders. ğŸ’¡âœ… What's happening here?In my Calculators class, the add() method is overloaded in 5 ways:add(int, int)add(float, float)add(double, double)add(int, float)add(float, int)Each method prints the exact combination of arguments it's invoked withâ€”clearly demonstrating how Java determines which method to run at compile time based on argument types. This is Compile-Time (Static) Polymorphism.ğŸ§ª Test Results (from the code):c.add(10, 20);           // int-intc.add(10.5f, 20.5f);     // float-floatc.add(10.5, 20.5);       // double-doublec.add(10, 20.5f);        // int-floatc.add(10.5f, 20);        // float-intGrateful to mentors like Syed Zabi Ulla Sir and Raghav Garg Sir for the constant motivation. ğŸ™hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverloading hashtag#CleanCode hashtag#DSA hashtag#LearnJava hashtag#30DaysOfCode hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#TechLearning hashtag#CodeNewbie hashtag#CompileTimePolymorphism hashtag#LinkedInLearning

If you're starting with STM32 Nucleo board with HAL...Most tutorials on YouTube recommend using STM32CubeMXâ€™s graphical interface. Itâ€™s beginner-friendly, no doubt. But if you want to understand things deeper by writing code manually, hereâ€™s something important you should know.# My Experience & What Went WrongI was following a tutorial where the instructor used the graphical interface just onceâ€”only for initial project setup so that CubeMX brings in the necessary HAL libraries. After that, all the coding was done manually.While following the steps:1. I deleted some core files as shown in the video (Iâ€™ve marked them in the image below).2. I wrote a basic LED blink code to test using HAL and used a for-loop based delay, which worked fine but using loops for delay isnâ€™t good practice.3. So I replaced that with HAL_Delay()â€”and the LED stopped blinking. It just stayed ON all the time.( PS: When using HAL_Delay(), you need to setup first SystemClock. By default cubemx also generate that code initially during project creation, you can use same. )Tried everythingâ€”debugging, checking RCC and SysTickâ€”nothing worked.Finally, I created a new project, this time:Only wrote my custom code inside main.cDidnâ€™t delete any CubeMX-generated filesAnd guess what? It worked perfectly.# Lesson LearnedLet CubeMX generate the base project once. Donâ€™t delete anything from itâ€”even if it looks useless.Those files are important. Some of them handle startup, clocks, SysTick, and even interrupt vectors behind the scenes.# Step-by-Step: Creating a Manual HAL Project (Without CubeMX)1. Create a new STM32 project in STM32CubeIDEâ†’ Select your MCU (e.g., STM32F446RE)2. Once the CubeMX window opens, go to Pinout view and click â€œClear Pinoutâ€â†’ This gives you a minimal project with boilerplate code and necessary HAL setup3. Open main.c and remove the default logicâ†’ Start writing your own code manuallyâ†’ But make sure you donâ€™t go back to CubeMX after that, or it will overwrite your changes4. If you plan to use both graphical + manual setup, use the same main.c and only write code inside these safe blocks:/* USER CODE BEGIN 0 */// your code/* USER CODE END 0 */CubeMX will leave your code untouched inside these markers.Follow me on LinkedIn for more tips: https://lnkd.in/drr2xUDjhashtag#stm32 hashtag#microcontrollers hashtag#embedded hashtag#hal hashtag#cmsis hashtag#lowlevelprogramming hashtag#stm32cubeide hashtag#baremetal hashtag#driverdevelopment hashtag#embeddedengineering hashtag#nucleo

Letâ€™s dive into the concept of the Java String Pool and uncover its significance. ğŸš€ğŸ§µ What is the Java String Pool?The Java String Pool is a special area in the heap memory ğŸ§  where Java stores string literals. When you create a string literal, Java checks the pool to see if an identical string already exists. If it does, Java reuses the reference, saving memory and improving performance. This process is called string interning ğŸ”.ğŸ’ Why is it Important?ğŸ”¹ Memory Optimization: Reuses immutable string objects to reduce   memory overhead. ğŸ”¹ Performance Enhancement: Less memory usage = faster garbage collection ğŸ§¹ and smoother app performance âš¡. ğŸ”¹ Consistency: Identical string literals share the same reference, ensuring consistency across the application. âœ”ï¸ String a = "Java"; String b = "Java"; System.out.println(a == b); // Outputs: true âœ…ğŸ“Œ Key Takeaway:Understanding the String Pool helps you write memory-efficient Java applications ğŸ’¼. As a student still preparing for object-oriented programming ğŸ› ï¸, I recognize that my perspective may not fully capture the complexities of professional development.However, my initial foray into Java and C# revealed a fundamental difference in understanding the basic concepts. Javaâ€™s often-criticized verbosity surprisingly served as a more transparent guide, encouraging a deeper understanding of the inner workings of OOP.On the other hand, C#â€™s elegance and conciseness, while appealing for cleaner code, occasionally obscured crucial details that Javaâ€™s explicitness reveals. This raises a fundamental question for fellow learners: to what extent can syntactic abstraction, while increasing the productivity of experienced developers, make it difficult for beginners to internalize fundamental principles? As insightfully discussed in Forrest Knight video, Javaâ€™s verbosity and apparent clutter can indeed be an initial obstacle for beginners.Despite the undeniable market forces that influence the adoption of these languages, my initial experience tends to value an approach that advocates conceptual transparency, even if that means more verbose syntax. And that's OK.As someone living in Buenos Aires, I get why that rubs some people the wrong way.But hereâ€™s the reality: the local job market just doesnâ€™t compare.A friend of mine is a middle manager at one of the biggest banks here. Fifteen years of experience, leadership role, and he makes $2,500 a month.Meanwhile, someone with a few years of marketing experience working remotely can earn more than that.So yeah, weâ€™re doing the same work for less money than our US counterparts.But weâ€™re also living in countries with lower costs, closer to family, and with access to opportunities we wouldnâ€™t have had otherwise.Some people hear this and immediately jump to â€œexploitation.â€ And donâ€™t get me wrong â€” there are companies out there taking advantage.But paying less isnâ€™t automatically a bad thing.Itâ€™s a reflection of different economies, not different levels of respect.Hopefully, wages in countries like mine will rise as our economies grow. But in the meantime, global remote work gives people here a way to level up their lives.Thatâ€™s a win in my book.

Title: Java Program to Analyze Student MarksIntroduction:This Java program is designed to assist in analyzing student performance by collecting marks for a fixed set of subjects and then computing useful insights such as the total marks, average, highest and lowest marks, and the corresponding subjects.Functionality Overview:The program begins by prompting the user to enter marks for a predefined list of subjects: Tamil, English, Maths, Science, and Social. The marks entered by the user are stored in an integer array.Core Processing:Once the marks are collected, the program performs the following tasks:1. Total Marks Calculation: It adds up all the marks using a loop.2. Average Marks: The total is divided by the number of subjects to get the average.3. Identifying Extremes: It finds the highest and lowest marks by comparing each subject's score. Along with the marks, the program also tracks which subjects have these scores.Output:After processing the data, the program displays:Total marksAverage marksThe subject with the highest marksThe subject with the lowest marksConclusion:This program is a simple yet effective example of how arrays, loops, and conditionals can be used in Java to manage and analyze student data. It helps reinforce key programming concepts while being practical for real-world applications like report card generation.hashtag#snsinstitutions hashtag#snsdesignthikers hashtag#designthinking

Day 20 of 100daysofcudaprogramming: - Chapter 6 of the PMPP book completed- CUDA Optimization Checklist:- 1. Maximize Occupancy: a. Hides pipeline/memory latency. b. Tune threads/block, shared memory, registers.- 2. Coalesced Global Memory Accesses: a. Reduces memory traffic, stalls. b. Load coalesced to shared memory, rearrange thread/data mapping.- 3. Minimize Control Divergence: a. Improves SIMD efficiency b. Align thread workloads, rearrange data- 4. Tile Reused Data: a. Cuts global memory accesses b. Store tiles in shared memory/registers- 5. Privatization: a. Avoids atomic contention b. Use private copies, update universal copy later- 6. Thread Coarsening: a. Reduces redundant work/sync b. Assign multiple tasks per thread

Core JavaDay-19Encapsulation:---------------------Encapsulation is a process of making variables are private and accessing through methodsÂ public those are getters and setters.-If we declare all variables are private, then it is tightly coupled class.-If we declare any one variable is not private, then it is loosely coupled class.-setters-Always declare return type as void.-getters-Always declare its respective return type and does't have any parameter.Benefits of Encapsulation:1. Data Hiding: Encapsulation protects the data from unauthorized access.2.Increased Flexibility: It allows the internal implementation to be changed without affecting the external code.3.Improved Maintainability:  It helps in maintaining the code by keeping the data private and providing controlled access to modify it. 4.Reusability:  Encapsulated code is easier to reuse in other parts of the application.5.Testing: Encapsulated units can be tested independently.BILLA HEMANTH10000 Coders

ğŸš€ Day 04 of my hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA challenge! ğŸš€1)Today I tackled a parallel partial-sum (inclusive scan) kernel on the GPU:Summed two input elements per thread (input[idx] + input[idx+blockDim.x]) into shared memory for coalesced loads.2)Added guarded-load logic so threads past the array end read zero, avoiding out-of-bounds errors.3) Laid out a tree-based inclusive scan in shared memory, doing O(log blockSize) strides with __syncthreads() for each step.4) Computed gridSize = (N + 2*blockSize â€“ 1)/(2*blockSize) so every element is processed when each block handles 2Ã—blockSize inputs.5)Wrapped all CUDA API calls in a CUDA_CHECK macro to catch and report errors immediately.ğŸ”¹ Key takeawaysIn-place prefix sum: Implemented a scalable tree-based scan pattern in shared memory.Memory coalescing: Two-element threads maximize bandwidth by loading contiguous data.Bounds safety: Guarded-load idioms ensure correctness when N isnâ€™t a multiple of 2Ã—blockSize.Grid-block sizing: 2 elements per thread halves the number of required blocks, improving occupancy.ğŸ“‚ Check out the code and follow along: ğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/dwkvia42Would love your feedback: ğŸ’¬ Any tips for further optimizing scan kernels? ğŸ‘ Drop a like if you enjoy these daily deep dives!hashtag#CUDA hashtag#GPUProgramming hashtag#ParallelComputing hashtag#PrefixSum hashtag#SharedMemory hashtag#PMPP hashtag#100DaysOfCUDA

As a student entering the tech industry, Iâ€™ve witnessed the growing permanence of remote software engineering. What started as a pandemic workaround has evolved into a powerful model for productivity, collaboration, and inclusion.A recent GitLab Remote Work Report (2023) revealed that 86% of developers feel more productive working remotely, and 80% prefer it to in-office setups. For students, these numbers arenâ€™t just statsâ€”they represent opportunity. Remote work is giving us access to real-world experiences we wouldnâ€™t otherwise have.One of my most meaningful remote experiences was developing a Unix-style shell in C, called atlas-simple_shell. This wasnâ€™t a tutorial projectâ€”it was a fully functional command-line interpreter with features like piping, error handling, and environment variable management.What made this experience powerful wasnâ€™t just the codeâ€”it was how my team and I collaborated. All of us were based in the same city, but none of us worked in the same place. Some preferred early mornings at the library, others coded from home or cafÃ©s late into the night. Remote work let each of us stay in our flow and schedule.We used GitHub to manage version control and pull requests, and met via Zoom when syncs were needed. Our coordination through Slack meant we could keep momentum without waiting on each other. This asynchronous setup didnâ€™t just help the project succeedâ€”it taught us to communicate, document, and organize like professionals.Remote collaboration doesnâ€™t lower expectationsâ€”it raises them. Working asynchronously demands better communication, ownership, and planning. Hereâ€™s what remote professionalism meant for me:Clear Communication: Writing clean, detailed pull request messages and updates.Accountability: Sticking to deadlines, even if we werenâ€™t being directly managed.Technical Documentation: Creating READMEs and code comments that made the project usable and understandable for everyone on the team.Collaboration Without Co-location: Knowing when to push forward independently vs. when to sync with teammates.These habits are exactly what top engineering teams need, whether remote or not.Remote software engineering has changed how students like me access experience and build skills. I didnâ€™t need a physical internship to practice real collaboration. I learned how to handle source control in a team, maintain project structure, and debug othersâ€™ code.Even more exciting is how inclusive this model is. When location is no longer a constraint, more people can participate. Students from different backgrounds, responsibilities, and living situations can still contributeâ€”and thrive.Remote work helped me work smarter, stay motivated, and build something meaningful with others on my own terms. Itâ€™s a practice Iâ€™m taking into the professional world with confidence.SourcesGitLab Remote Work Report 2023 â€“ GitLabStack Overflow Blog â€“ How Remote Engineering Teams Can Succeed

Some thoughts on hashtag#remoteWorkI donâ€™t think I need to explain how remote work has evolved in recent years. Before COVID-19 (pre-2021), remote work was a rare privilegeâ€”something only a lucky few could negotiate. But during the pandemic, it became the norm, especially in computer-based fields like software engineering, analytics, and marketing.Over the past few months, however, we've seen increasing pushback. Some companies have gone as far as mandating a full return to the officeâ€”not just hybrid, but five days a week. I wanted to reflect on what feels like a regression.I call it a regression because, had it not been for a global pandemic, many companies would still believe that productivity could only be guaranteed through physical presenceâ€”by clocking in and out, sitting at a desk under watchful eyes. But we proved otherwise. Productivity didnâ€™t tank. The world didnâ€™t stop. The sun didnâ€™t rise from the west.That said, remote work wasnâ€™t without its challenges. Some individuals abused the flexibilityâ€”juggling multiple full-time roles at once and damaging the trust-based relationship needed for remote work to thrive.Iâ€™ve also noticed that some recent graduates, who entered the workforce in this new remote-first world, struggled with engagement. Thrust into what felt like a dream scenario, some lacked the structure or mentorship that in-person environments naturally provideâ€”leading to performance issues.But letâ€™s not allow a few bad examples to overshadow the bigger picture. Remote work may be one of the greatest professional shifts of our time. At least for me, hereâ€™s what itâ€™s meant:1.  I gained back over 2 hours a day from commutingâ€”thatâ€™s 700 hours a year. Less commuting = less stress and wasted energy = more productivity.2. Thatâ€™s time I now spend with my family, myselfâ€”or yes, sometimes, even working.3. Most importantly, I got to watch my baby girl grow up. Every day. From the moment she was born until now, two years later, Iâ€™ve seen her in her element. Thatâ€™s priceless. Itâ€™s something many of our fathers missedâ€”and I donâ€™t think we should repeat that mistake.4. I have more control over my timSo how do we make remote work a win-win?1. Trust, but verify: Build accountability through regular check-ins, clear deliverables, and performance metrics.2. Hybrid mentorship: Pair remote flexibility with in-person or virtual mentorship to support junior talent.3. Cultural investment: Create intentional moments for team bonding and alignmentâ€”digitally or otherwise.4. Results over hours: Focus on outcomes, not desk time. Empower employees to own their time.Remote work isnâ€™t perfectâ€”but neither was the old way. Letâ€™s not lose sight of the enormous good it can bring, when done right. Iâ€™m genuinely grateful to Klarna for embracing this cultureâ€”striking a healthy balance between drive and productivity, while honoring the importance of family and well-being. Letâ€™s evolve, not revert.hashtag#remotework hashtag#futureofwork hashtag#productivity

Itâ€™s all about writing multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or orders. ğŸ’¡âœ… What's happening here?In my Calculators class, the add() method is overloaded in 5 ways:add(int, int)add(float, float)add(double, double)add(int, float)add(float, int)Each method prints the exact combination of arguments it's invoked withâ€”clearly demonstrating how Java determines which method to run at compile time based on argument types. If you're starting with STM32 Nucleo board with HAL...Most tutorials on YouTube recommend using STM32CubeMXâ€™s graphical interface. Itâ€™s beginner-friendly, no doubt. But if you want to understand things deeper by writing code manually, hereâ€™s something important you should know.# My Experience & What Went WrongI was following a tutorial where the instructor used the graphical interface just onceâ€”only for initial project setup so that CubeMX brings in the necessary HAL libraries. After that, all the coding was done manually.While following the steps:1. I deleted some core files as shown in the video (Iâ€™ve marked them in the image below).2. I wrote a basic LED blink code to test using HAL and used a for-loop based delay, which worked fine but using loops for delay isnâ€™t good practice.3. So I replaced that with HAL_Delay()â€”and the LED stopped blinking. It just stayed ON all the time.( PS: When using HAL_Delay(), you need to setup first SystemClock. By default cubemx also generate that code initially during project creation, you can use same. )Tried everythingâ€”debugging, checking RCC and SysTickâ€”nothing worked.Finally, I created a new project, this time:Only wrote my custom code inside main.cDidnâ€™t delete any CubeMX-generated filesAnd guess what? It worked perfectly.# Lesson LearnedLet CubeMX generate the base project once. Donâ€™t delete anything from itâ€”even if it looks useless.Those files are important. Some of them handle startup, clocks, SysTick, and even interrupt vectors behind the scenes.# Step-by-Step: Creating a Manual HAL Project (Without CubeMX)1. Create a new STM32 project in STM32CubeIDEâ†’ Select your MCU (e.g., STM32F446RE)2. Once the CubeMX window opens, go to Pinout view and click â€œClear Pinoutâ€â†’ This gives you a minimal project with boilerplate code and necessary HAL setup3. Open main.c and remove the default logicâ†’ Start writing your own code manuallyâ†’ But make sure you donâ€™t go back to CubeMX after that, or it will overwrite your changes4. If you plan to use both graphical + manual setup, use the same main.c and only write code inside these safe blocks:/* USER CODE BEGIN 0 */// your code/* USER CODE END 0 */CubeMX will leave your code untouched inside these markers.Follow me on LinkedIn for more tips: https://lnkd.in/drr2xUDjhashtag#stm32 hashtag#microcontrollers hashtag#embedded hashtag#hal hashtag#cmsis hashtag#lowlevelprogramming hashtag#stm32cubeide hashtag#baremetal hashtag#driverdevelopment hashtag#embeddedengineering hashtag#nucleo

ğŸ’¡ Ever wondered how Java manages memory so efficiently when dealing with strings? Letâ€™s dive into the concept of the Java String Pool and uncover its significance. ğŸš€ğŸ§µ What is the Java String Pool?The Java String Pool is a special area in the heap memory ğŸ§  where Java stores string literals. When you create a string literal, Java checks the pool to see if an identical string already exists. If it does, Java reuses the reference, saving memory and improving performance. This process is called string interning ğŸ”.ğŸ’ Why is it Important?ğŸ”¹ Memory Optimization: Reuses immutable string objects to reduce   memory overhead. ğŸ”¹ Performance Enhancement: Less memory usage = faster garbage collection ğŸ§¹ and smoother app performance âš¡. ğŸ”¹ Consistency: Identical string literals share the same reference, ensuring consistency across the application. âœ”ï¸ String a = "Java"; String b = "Java"; System.out.println(a == b); // Outputs: true âœ…ğŸ“Œ Key Takeaway:Understanding the String Pool helps you write memory-efficient Java applications ğŸ’¼. It's a subtle yet powerful feature that underscores Javaâ€™s design for performance and reliability. ğŸ› ï¸hashtag#Java hashtag#StringPool hashtag#JavaTips hashtag#JavaMemory hashtag#JavaOptimization hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#JavaLearning hashtag#MemoryManagement

But in the meantime, global remote work gives people here a way to level up their lives.Thatâ€™s a win in my book.

Title: Java Program to Analyze Student MarksIntroduction:This Java program is designed to assist in analyzing student performance by collecting marks for a fixed set of subjects and then computing useful insights such as the total marks, average, highest and lowest marks, and the corresponding subjects.Functionality Overview:The program begins by prompting the user to enter marks for a predefined list of subjects: Tamil, English, Maths, Science, and Social. The marks entered by the user are stored in an integer array.Core Processing:Once the marks are collected, the program performs the following tasks:1. Total Marks Calculation: It adds up all the marks using a loop.2. Average Marks: The total is divided by the number of subjects to get the average.3. Identifying Extremes: It finds the highest and lowest marks by comparing each subject's score. Along with the marks, the program also tracks which subjects have these scores.Output:After processing the data, the program displays:Total marksAverage marksThe subject with the highest marksThe subject with the lowest marksConclusion:This program is a simple yet effective example of how arrays, loops, and conditionals can be used in Java to manage and analyze student data. It helps reinforce key programming concepts while being practical for real-world applications like report card generation.hashtag#snsinstitutions hashtag#snsdesignthikers hashtag#designthinking

Day 20 of 100daysofcudaprogramming: - Chapter 6 of the PMPP book completed- CUDA Optimization Checklist:- 1. Maximize Occupancy: a. Hides pipeline/memory latency. b. Tune threads/block, shared memory, registers.- 2. Coalesced Global Memory Accesses: a. Reduces memory traffic, stalls. b. Load coalesced to shared memory, rearrange thread/data mapping.- 3. Minimize Control Divergence: a. Improves SIMD efficiency b. Align thread workloads, rearrange data- 4. Tile Reused Data: a. Cuts global memory accesses b. Store tiles in shared memory/registers- 5. Privatization: a. Avoids atomic contention b. Use private copies, update universal copy later- 6. Thread Coarsening: a. Reduces redundant work/sync b. Assign multiple tasks per thread

BLE Scanning: The app scans for nearby Bluetooth devices, specifically targeting the carâ€™s Bluetooth signal.2. Connection: Upon finding the target device, it initiates the GATT connection.3. Command Handling: Once connected, commands like "auth", "open door" or "close door" are sent and executed via Bluetooth characteristics and descriptors.4. Real-time Updates: The app listens for notifications from the car, ensuring actions are performed successfully and feedback is received promptly.
